Name: Excerpt from "Gotham"
Citation: Pages 582-583. Burrows, Edwin G., and Mike Wallace. Gotham: A History of New York City to 1898. First issued as an Oxford University Press paperback, Oxford University Press, 2000.
Title: New York Marble Cemetery was founded in 1831
Text Box: "New York had banned burials south of Canal Street, and by 1830 several enterprising businessmen had opened New York Marble Cemetery as a profit-making venture.  The city's first nonsectarian cemetery -- its 156 underground vaults were open to the wealthy of any faith -- was situated on a half-acre plot just west of Second Avenue between Second and Third streets.  An inscription blazoned on its east wall read PLACE OF BURIAL FOR GENTLEMEN.  It was so successful they opened a second one, a block east, in 1832.  Further annexes were ruled out the following year by the real estate boom, which drove the value of downtown lots to such heights that the City Council extended the ban on new interments north to 14th Street. "

Name: New York Marble Cemetery Entrance
Caption: Inscription at the entrance of the New York Marble Cemetery, Manhattan's first public, non-sectarian cemetery. Not to be confused with the New York City Marble Cemetery, the second public, non-secterian cemetery in New York, founded one year after.
Description: Color photo of inscription on top of the New York Marble Cemetery entrance door
Text Box: Inscription the entrance of the New York Marble Cemetery, Manhattan's first public, non-secterian cemetery. Not to be confused with the New York City Marble Cemetery, the second public, non-secterian cemetery in New York, founded one year after.

Name: New York Marble Cemetery Marble Vaults
Caption: A vault tablet from the New York Marble Cemetery. The inscription is not clear but the first name seems to be "George Bowen" and "Richard B.Brown, who according to the New York Marble Cemetery's website were interred in 1848 and 1860, in vault 8. The website shows that around 16 people are interred in vault #8, most of which have the last name "Bowen"
Description: Color photo of a vault tablet in the New York Marble Cemetery
Title: New York Marble Cemetery Marble Vaults
Text Box: The cemetery does not have any tombstones or markers on the ground, instead it had 156 vaults marked on the walls with a marble plaque. The plaques had the names of the owners of each pair of vaults that were next to each other.
SubText1: The New York Marble Cemetery plot in the block between the Bowery and Second avenue and Second and Third streets offers an opportunity for the acquisition of a needed playground for that location. The cemetery is now but little hard and perhaps could be obtained of its owners at small expense and transformed into a playground. Burial there has always been in vault and the dead could be easily removed. The cemetery is a great garden surrounded by a high stone wall, and would seem to be well fitted for the establishment of a playground with gymnastic apparatus. The only school playground which New York has had her fire, is an old cemetery on the other side of Second avenue, near by, which has acquired under similar circumstances a few years ago, after it had ceased to be of use as a burial ground.

Name: Image of broken memorial urn in the Marble Cemetery
Caption: Image broken memorial urn in the Marble Cemetery in the center of the block bound by 2nd Avenue, 2nd Street, 3rd Street and Bowery--proposed for use as a playground.
Description: Image broken memorial urn in the Marble Cemetery in the center of the block bound by 2nd Avenue, 2nd Street, 3rd Street and Bowery--proposed for use as a playground.

Title: New York Marble Cemetery as seen by Jacob Riis
Text Box: This photo is from a collection of photos taken by Jacob Riis in 1885, the reformer who later in 1887 on proposes to user the New York Marble Cemetery as a playground.

Name: New York Times Article: Movement to Remove New York Marble Cemetery
Citation: "TENEMENTS MAY MARCH OVER OLD GRAVEYARDS: MOVEMENT TO REMOVE NEW YORK MARBLE CEMETERY. FAMOUS NAMES ON SLABS LORILLARDS, BEEKMANS, AND VARICKS REST THERE -- MARBLE CEMETERY, NEARBY, MIGHT HAVE TO GO." New York Times (1857-1922), Mar 19, 1905, pp. 2. ProQuest, http://ezproxy.gc.cuny.edu/login?url=https://www-proquest-com.ezproxy.gc.cuny.edu/historical-newspapers/tenements-may-march-over-old-graveyards/docview/96570180/se-2?accountid=7287.
Title: Another failed attempt to demolish the New York Marble Cemetery
Text Box: Several well-known families in this city have received circulars in the last day or two from the law office of Emmet & Robinson, telling them that the ground in which their forebears are buried is no longer suitable for their resting place. The spot to which these circulars refer is the almost completely concealed graveyard on Second Avenue between Second and Third Streets, down on the old records of the city as The New York Marble Cemetery.

Name: New York Marble Cemetery as a Profit Making venture
Citation: Foner, Eric. Gateway to Freedom: The Hidden History of the Underground Railroad. First edition. W.W. Norton & Company, 2015.
Title: New York Marble Cemetery as a profit-making venture: A look into racialized restrictions on voting in the city
Text Box: One aspect of the first days of the cemetery is how it was built as a profit-making venture. The early vaults were sold for 250$ at the time. I tried to put this into context within New York City’s abolition process at the time. Before 1821, in order to allow people to vote, New Yor City had a property restriction set for people to vote, in the sense where you need to own a specific amount of property to cast a ballot. During this time, New York was in the middle of a gradual abolition of slavery. However, after 1821, the property restrictions on voting became racialized. By that I mean that they were completely removed for white people and imposed on black people. So basically, the only way that the constitution allowed black people to vote is if they had $250 in property, which at that time was almost impossible. The numbers show that.. in 1826, only sixteen black men in the city were able to vote. And this did not change much in the time where the cemetery was founded. The fact that the vaults were also sold for $250 is very telling of the type of people that the “non-sectarian” cemetery aimed to cater for. It is safe to assume that the cemetery was built on exclusionary practices that excluded black people from being buried there and it will always carry that legacy
SubText1: "Despite this burgeoning community life, the living conditions of black New Yorkers deteriorated. Even as gradual abolition proceeded, racism became more entrenched in the city’s culture. Before 1821, non-racial property restrictions determined which men could vote. But in that year, while eliminating property qualifications for whites, the state’s constitutional convention imposed a prohibitive $250 requirement for blacks. By 1826, only sixteen black men in the city were able to cast a ballot."

Title: Historical New York Marble Cemetery Now
Text Box: In 1969, the cemetery became a New York City Landmark and 1980 it was placed in the National Register of Historic Places.
